column4: I am setting up my home server, now I do wonder that if I have address mysite.operator.com assigned on ISP side for my connection and they are redirecting to port 80 any traffic coming to that address, could I get multiple virtual hosts to work like mysite.operator.com/site1 and mysite.operator.com/site2 etc ?
do you mean setting multiple pages to the same port?
I mean that is it possible to have multiple independent websites with virtual host setup when I got solid address from my ISP for my home server
adress is in form adress.operator.com
do you have you apache server running on your machine , right?!
Yes
but I don't figure why I got errors of overlapping virtual host setting
it is possible, have a look at reverse proxy on apache
I will do that
this will basically, tell the computer to handle all incoming connections to port 80, but inside apache you will tell it to assign to different ports , depending on the address
I just want to get my home server secure before I put it to use I have planned to... since there comes confidential data and other things I want it to be secure
i just google some stuff for you...it seems a nice source http://www.apachetutor.org/admin/reverseproxies
I did check that out and it was not quite what I was looking for
I am trying to get this to work : address.operator.com and adress.operator.com/otherwebsite to work with virtual hosts with apache
But I don't think that just to be possible
if i understood you well, you have one valid ip address assigned by your ISP. And all incoming requests to you go to port 80, right?
I actually got a valid subdomain adress, now what I try to figure out is that could I setup multiple websites on single apache server to my adress
then you wanted somehow, that different request (using different addresses) www.myserver.com/site1 , www.myserver.com/site2 , would reach the correct ones ?
Yeah something like that, but now when I start to more think of it, I think it just is not possible doe to factors not depending on me...
well i am not getting the idea...if you want to set up the thing i described above, is just going for reverse proxies
Because I think that I would need to have dns record somewhere for those multiple addresses and those would redirect to different virtual hosts on my server, which I don't have atm
but you just said that you ISP, provided you a subdomain, right? if you have a valid subdomain, then you already have a valid dns server where it is registered

yeah I do and what I am trying to get done is that I could have multiple websites which appear in different sub directories like (address.operator.com , address.operator.com/site2 address.com/site3) all served as apache virtual hosts from my home server and each in own directory
